comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] You're right. If you copy the original size image into an imaging app and do a histogram equalisation on it, the windows are a pretty clear match. A sharpening filter shows it up pretty well too.

comment._content: PSP these days. I used to do R&D for medical on space image analysis and compression systems though.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: So why's there no picture today? Has some ill befallen miss National Library?

comment.author: 29492435@N02

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: Right folks if you look at the middle of the ridge line of St. Michael's you'll see a bump. If you then look at the companion photo which was taken from higher up and a slightly different angle you can see the "bump" is green and is the dome of the Town Hall finished in 1901 !!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] Are you sure? The tower outline is marked on the 1858 town plan. Possibly finished means they got the door completed: www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/yourplaceandmine/fermanagh/...

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] www.doeni.gov.uk/niea/fermanagh-2.pdf Town Hall. Townhall Street, Enniskillen. This imposing building erected 1898 - 1901 was designed by William Scott and built of Carrickreagh stone.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: It would seem we have two conflicting dates for the building of the Town Hall.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I think we need OS man Niall to adjudicate. I could well be misinterpreting the map date. It's called OS-9-18-2-4(1858 - 1858) from a series called Town Plans Edition 2 (1843-1896). I'm assuming that means it's from 1858 but it may not.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: I think the later of these links rules out 1858 as William Scott wasn't born until 1871. archiseek.com/2009/1901-ownhall-enniskillen-co-fermanagh/ www.dia.ie/architects/view/4766/SCOTT-WILLIAMALPHONSUS

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
Ah. That's a much better picture. You can see that the town hall marked on the map is much smaller, though it includes a tower in the same place. Unless the tower was retained, I think you're correct with your date of 1901.
Edit: Actually, the tower's not in the same place.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: It looks to me as if there was a town hall on that site in 1858, but it was not the same town hall with the clock-tower which we see today, which was finished in 1901.

comment.author: 97370691@N05
comment._content:
Hey Niall and anyone else on here as you guys seem to be up on your local knowledge!  Where would I find information on distilleries in Enniskillen.  I believe there was the Powell distillery in 1826 possibly run by an excise man Robert Armstrong. Vague details though.  I was searching for that and came across Nialls indication of a distillery from an earlier time!  Any information on whisky distillation in Enniskillen and fermanagh would be rewarded with a dram!
I'm compiling a historical project based around spirits.
Thanks

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You won't get a better offer all year - a dram for information from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/97370691@N05]! Feel guilty now that I don't offer liquid incentives...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/97370691@N05] Not at all a local or an expert, I only know what can be learned from my patented HAGS (Half-Assed Google Search). This OS map from 1837 shows one distillery at the Erne bridge. On the 1858 map, that building is labelled Ulster Canal Company Stores. There is a Distillery nearby on the Eastern side of the bridge, where the Spar is on streetview. That's the one I highlighted on the photo above. The topographical dictionary of Ireland of 1837 says: there are two distilleries and a brewery.

comment.author: 97370691@N05
comment._content:
Thanks Niall great work.  I'm still on the hunt though.  Found a guy called Robert Armstrong who was legally producing whiskey in town.  Think he was also an excise man.
Dram still stands for any other info from anyone.  Or any other photos/pictures that show the roof/chimney/building.
Thanks guys
